sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• colestilan has central marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Chronic kidney disease stage 5, in patients receiving hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis - Hyperphosphatemia: initial, 6 to 9 g/day ORALLY in 2 to 3 divided doses; may increase dose by 3 g/day (1 g 3 times daily) in 2 to 3 weekly intervals based on serum phosphorus concentrations; MAX 15 g/day (5 g 3 times daily) (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients younger than 18 years

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment, not studied in pre-dialysis patients
  • hepatic impairment, severe: use not recommended

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Chronic kidney disease stage 5, in patients receiving hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis - Hyperphosphatemia

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• bowel obstruction
  • hypersensitivity to colestilan or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• albumin, serum, less than 30 g/L; not recommended
  • biliary obstruction; not recommended
  • conditions that predispose to gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage (eg, recent history of GI hemorrhage, gastritis, diverticulosis, colitis, hemorrhoids)
  • dysphagia or swallowing disorders; not recommended
  • folate deficiency due to impaired intestinal absorption may occur with long-term treatment; monitoring recommended
  • gastrointestinal (GI) disorders, severe (eg, chronic or severe constipation, intestinal stenosis, intestinal diverticulum, sigmoid colitis, GI ulcers, recent major GI surgery); not recommended
  • hepatic impairment, severe; not recommended
  • hypocalcemia or hypercalcemia may occur; monitoring recommended
  • hypothyroidism; monitoring recommended when using concomitant levothyroxine
  • intestinal obstruction and ileus/subileus has been reported; may be preceded by constipation; monitoring of constipated patients recommended; consider alternative treatment if severe constipation or other severe gastrointestinal symptoms develop
  • ion balance, systemic changes (chloride increase and bicarbonate decrease) may occur
  • malabsorption, concomitant use of coumarin anticoagulants, or other predisposing conditions for vitamin K or fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies; monitoring recommended
  • peritonitis, recent history of in peritoneal dialysis patients; not recommended
  • seizure disorders; not recommended

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypocalcemia (1% to less than 10%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal discomfort (1% to less than 10%), Abdominal distension (1% to less than 10%), Abdominal pain (1% to less than 10%), Constipation (1% to less than 10%), Decrease in appetite (1% to less than 10%), Diarrhea (1% to less than 10%), Flatulence (1% to less than 10%), Gastritis (1% to less than 10%), Indigestion (1% to less than 10%), Nausea (1% to less than 10%), Vomiting (1% to less than 10%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Coronary arteriosclerosis (0.01% to less than 0.1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction (0.01% to less than 0.1%), Dysphagia (0.1% to less than 1%), Esophagitis (0.1% to less than 1%), Gastroenteritis (0.1% to less than 1%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (0.1% to less than 1%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • (tablets) swallow whole
  • (granules) take whole as 1 dose from sachet
  • administer with or immediately after meals with enough water to ensure swallowing
  • patients should be encouraged to adhere to a low-phosphate diet
